channel.title: NYT > World

item.title: Deadly Bombs Hit Campaign Event in Iraq
item.description: An attack in Baquba left 20 people dead and heightened concerns about violence in advance of local elections scheduled for April 20.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Egyptian Muslims and Christians in Fatal Clash Near Cairo
item.description: Security officials said five people died and eight were wounded in violence in the town of Khusus.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Tamam Salam Asked to Form a Government in Lebanon
item.description: Tammam Salam was officially named the new prime minister of Lebanon on Saturday after receiving a string of endorsements from the country’s warring factions over the past few days.
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA

item.title: Mandela, Treated for Pneumonia, Is Released From Hospital
item.description: Nelson Mandela, the 94-year-old former president of South Africa, was released from a hospital in Johannesburg after treatment for pneumonia.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Afghan Suicide Attack Kills 5 Americans
item.description: The bomb, which killed three soldiers and two civilians, was the deadliest single attack against United States forces this year,
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Europe Doesn’t Trust Its Politicians. What’s the Alternative?
item.description: Politicians are accustomed to taking the blame when things go wrong. Europe’s economic crisis is, however, provoking a wider backlash against political leaders seen as failing to practice what they preach.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Anti-eviction protestors in Madrid on Wednesday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Kim Jong-un’s Spanish Mouthpiece
item.description: North Korea’s leader looks increasingly isolated in his war of words with the outside world. But Pyongyang’s European spokesman says Kim Jong-un can still rely on a dedicated band of devotees abroad.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:credit: Korea Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un at a Workers' Party plenary on Sunday.

item.title: Nuclear Talks With Iran End Without Accord
item.description: The futility was certain to arouse renewed alarm, particularly from Israel, which had tempered its threats of a military strike in deference to diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Catherine Ashton, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, spoke at a news conference after negotiations over Iran’s disputed nuclear program broke off on Saturday in Almaty, Kazakhstan.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 5
item.description: A frog marriage on the outskirts of Guwahati, Assam.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Villagers solemnize a marriage between two frogs on the outskirts of Guwahati, Assam. The ceremony is conducted to appease the gods and pray for rain and good harvest.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 6
item.description: Investor concern on Korea; advances on exam grading; arrest shows China’s reach; and U.S. overhauls food aid.
item.dc:creator: By INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: South Korean army reservists in Seoul on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Building Collapse Near Mumbai Kills at Least 72
item.description: The collapse highlighted the problem of unsafe and illegal constructions tacked onto structures in the Mumbai area.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Rescue workers searched for survivors at the site of a collapsed residential building in Thane, on the outskirts of Mumbai, India, on Friday.

item.title: Death of Second Horse at Grand National Reignites Concerns Over Fences
item.description: The deaths of two horses at the Grand National meeting at Aintree Racecourse have dampened spirits before the main event and reignited concerns over the forbidding fences.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: In the Topham Steeplechase at Aintree Racecourse on Friday, Sam Twiston-Davies, in blue, fell from Little Josh, who broke a shoulder and was euthanized.

item.title: Writer of Times Op-Ed on Racism in Cuba Loses Job
item.description: The New York Times stood by the preparation of an opinion piece that Roberto Zurbano wrote before being removed from his post as an editor of a Cuban publishing house.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: The Lede: Discuss Tensions on the Korean Peninsula
item.description: To supplement the reporting of our colleagues on the ground, The Lede would like to hear from readers who live on the Korean peninsula or have family members there.
item.dc:creator: By SHREEYA SINHA and SU HYUN LEE
item.media:description: University students were among thousands of North Koreans who rallied against the United States in Pyongyang on March 29.

item.title: National Briefing | Washington: Visa Program for Skilled Workers Hits Limit Early
item.description: A visa program for skilled workers has hit its quota just days into the application period, United States Citizenship and Immigration Services said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Trade Deficit Narrows as Exports Increase
item.description: The gap between exports and imports fell 3.4 percent, to $43 billion in February.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Says Aid for Syria Refugees Is Running Out
item.description: A Unicef official says that with 1.25 million Syrians registered as refugees, “the needs are rising exponentially and we are broke.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Deir al-Zour, like many sites in Syria, has been laid waste by the war, leaving more Syrians fleeing as aid runs low.

item.title: Detecting Shift, U.S. Makes Case to China on North Korea
item.description: The Obama administration, seeing signs of Chinese frustration toward Pyongyang, is pressing China to crack down or face more of an American military presence in Asia.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: United States Army Patriot missile batteries were placed at an American air base in Osan, south of Seoul. Tension has risen in the region as North Korea continues to make bellicose threats.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Brazilian Campaign Strategist Expands His Winning Streak
item.description: João Santana, a hypercompetitive former journalist, exemplifies the growing influence of Brazilian political consultants in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: João Santana, seated in his office in São Paulo, Brazil.

item.title: Iran Says It Offers New Plan for Nuclear Program
item.description: Pyongyang’s nuclear-arms bombast and the cautious foreign response are hanging over resumed negotiations between Iran and the six big powers in unsettling ways.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Iran’s top nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili, right, during talks with officials from the European Union, the United States, Britain, France, China, Germany and Russia on Iran’s nuclear program.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy’s President Grants Pardon in Rendition Case
item.description: Italy’s president pardoned a United States Air Force colonel convicted in absentia for the abduction of an Egyptian terrorism suspect in Milan in a Central Intelligence Agency operation.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Portugal: Austerity Cuts Struck Down
item.description: Portugal’s Constitutional Court ruled that some pay cuts in this year’s state budget were unlawful, denying the government about $1.8 billion of predicted revenue.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnamese Farmers Sentenced to Prison for Resisting Eviction
item.description: A court sentenced four fish farmers to prison on Friday after finding them guilty of attempted murder for fighting an eviction squad with homemade guns and land mines last year.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Pope Seeks Decisive Action to Resolve Sexual Abuse Cases
item.description: Pope Francis directed the Vatican to act decisively on sexual abuse cases and to punish pedophile priests, saying the Roman Catholic Church’s credibility was on the line.
item.category: Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
